title: 113_hr4496
content: The Act may be cited as the "Covering People With Pre-Existing Conditions Act of 2014" and establishes universal access programs to improve high-risk pools and reinsurance markets for individuals with pre-existing conditions. Each State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. The State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a State reinsurance program to meet the requirement. The State must operate a qualified State reinsurance program or a qualifying State high-risk pool by January 1, 2015, funded by State premium assessments. States without a qualified high-risk pool must establish a State reinsurance program to meet the requirement. In the case of a State operating a current section 2745 qualified high-risk pool, it shall be treated as the operation of a qualified high-risk pool described in the Public Health Service Act. As of January 1, 2015, a pool must meet specific criteria to be considered a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. States can use premium assessment funds to transition from operating a non-qualifying pool to a qualified State reinsurance program. A qualified State reinsurance program, as defined in this section, must meet specific fiscal health criteria approved by the State Insurance Commissioner. A qualified State reinsurance program provides reinsurance for health insurance coverage in the small group market, based on a model established by the State. It can operate on a prospective or retrospective basis and protect health insurance issuers against annual aggregate spending of their enrollees. A qualified State reinsurance program offers reinsurance for health insurance in the small group market, protecting issuers against enrollees' catastrophic costs. It is considered a qualified high-risk pool under the Public Health Service Act. The State high-risk pool must provide at least two coverage options, including a high deductible health plan. The State high-risk pool must be funded with a stable source and eliminate waiting lists for coverage. It should offer options including a high deductible health plan coupled with a health savings account, and cover individuals who would qualify but for the disability waiting period under the Social Security Act. The State high-risk pool, funded with a stable source, must eliminate waiting lists for coverage. It should offer options like a high deductible health plan with a health savings account and cover individuals eligible for Medicare during the waiting period under the Social Security Act. The pool must limit premiums to 150% of the average standard risk rates, conduct education and outreach initiatives, and provide coverage for preventive services and disease management. Only citizens and nationals of the United States are eligible for State high-risk pools receiving funds under the Public Health Service Act. States must certify eligibility to receive funds. States must certify that all applicants for coverage in the qualifying State high risk pool provide documentation of citizenship or nationality consistent with the Social Security Act. The Secretary will maintain records to verify citizenship or nationality only once for each individual. As of January 1, 2015, a pool must be a qualifying State high risk pool to qualify under section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. The Secretary has the authority to waive requirements for State reinsurance programs and high risk pools. Additional funding is appropriated for carrying out section 2745 of the Public Health Service Act. The Act allocates $15 billion for fiscal years 2015-2024 and an extra $10 billion for fiscal years 2020-2024. Definitions for "health insurance coverage" and "health insurance issuer" are provided. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" is also defined. The term "current section 2745 qualified high risk pool" refers to the definition of "qualified high risk pool" under section 2745(g) of the Public Health Service Act. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The term "standard risk rate" is a rate determined under the State high risk pool by considering premium rates charged by other health insurance issuers. The term "State" refers to any of the 50 States or the District of Columbia. It involves individuals in the insurance market, established using actuarial techniques, reflecting anticipated claims experience and expenses for coverage.
